title: Benefits Realization
description: Distinguish project success (on time, budget, scope) from business success (revenue, ROI, value delivery).
objectives: Distinguish project success (delivery) from business success (benefits realized)
Categorize tangible (revenue, ROI) vs intangible (brand, satisfaction) benefits
Understand benefits are measured POST-project (3-24 months)
Recognize that benefits ownership transfers from PM to operations
Apply root cause analysis when benefits fall short

screens.headline: 3 Months Post-Opening. Project Successful. But Revenue $65K (Target $80K). Did We Deliver Value?

dialogue.text: Alex's project didn't deliver value! Revenue target not met!

counterpoint.text: Alex delivered the restaurant correctly. Carlos must realize benefits through operations. These are separate measures of success.

screens.learningHook: Can a project succeed but fail to realize business benefits? Who owns benefits realization?

screens.title: Benefits Analysis
screens.instructions: Categorize benefits, distinguish success types, and analyze shortfalls.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Tangible = financial (1,3,5,8). Intangible = qualitative (2,4,6,7). Both matter.
feedback.incorrect: Tangible appears on financial statements. Intangible is qualitative/strategic. Even rated items (4.5 stars) are intangible.

scenarios.title: Stage 2: Project vs Business Success
description: Riverside Plaza: On time, on budget, scope met

options.text: Project succeeded (delivered correctly) BUT business benefits partially realized. Project success ≠ automatic business success.

feedback.correct: Excellent! Project success (delivery) and business success (benefits) are SEPARATE measures. PM owns delivery. Operations owns benefits.
feedback.incorrect: Project met baselines (success). Benefits below target (partial). These are separate—project can succeed while benefits lag.

scenarios.title: Stage 3: Benefits Shortfall Response
description: Potential causes: traffic low, check size low, marketing weak, quality issues

options.text: Wait 3 more months for natural improvement
Root cause analysis: Why below target? (Traffic? Pricing? Quality? Marketing?) Implement corrective actions. Monitor monthly.
Declare project failure and request budget to redesign

feedback.correct: Perfect! Carlos owns benefits. Diagnose root cause, implement operational improvements, monitor progress. Don't blame PM or wait passively.
feedback.incorrect: Alex delivered correctly. Carlos must diagnose WHY benefits lag (traffic? pricing? quality?) and take operational action.

content.whySeparate: Did we build it correctly? (project) vs Did it deliver value? (business)

content.whyBothMatter: Tangible justifies investment. Intangible creates strategic advantage leading to future tangible benefits.

content.notPMsFault: Alex delivered the tool. Carlos uses it to realize value.

correct.text: I wanted to blame Alex for low revenue. But Alex delivered correctly (project success). My operations team must execute effectively (business success). These are separate measures.
I must diagnose WHY revenue is below target—traffic? pricing? quality?—then implement operational improvements. Benefits realization is MY responsibility, not Alex's.

screens.title: CRM Project Benefits
screens.context: CRM delivered on time/budget. Projected: 25% sales productivity, 15% retention, 200% ROI. Actual at 3 months: 8% productivity, 5% retention, 80% ROI.

questions.question: Sales VP blames you: 'Your CRM didn't deliver value!' Your response?

options.text: I'm sorry, let me investigate what went wrong
CRM works correctly (project success). Benefits depend on adoption and process change (operations).

questions.question: Likely root causes for benefits shortfall?

screens.title: Benefits Realization Mastery
screens.summary: Project success (delivery) ≠ Business success (benefits). PM delivers. Operations realizes value. Benefits measured 3-24 months post-project.
takeaways: PM owns delivery, Operations owns benefits
If benefits fall short, operations diagnoses root cause and takes action
Projects exist to deliver business VALUE, not just deliverables

artifacts.title: Benefits Realization Scorecard
artifacts.description: Track tangible and intangible benefits post-project

characterClosing.text: I learned: Alex gave me a functioning restaurant. I must achieve $80K revenue, 18% ROI, 4.5 rating. When revenue was $65K, I diagnosed root causes and implemented improvements. Benefits realization is MY responsibility.
